qas.question: What is systematically related to the numbers of species?
What animals are more sensitive to reduction in habitat area?

answers.text: Physically larger species and those living at lower latitudes or in forests or oceans

qas.question: How is a standardized ecosystem formed?
What leads to biodiversity loss is some countries?

answers.text: lack of property rights or lax law/regulatory enforcement

qas.question: What is systematically related to the numbers of communities?

plausible_answers.text: Physically larger species and those living at lower latitudes or in forests or oceans

qas.question: What animals are more sensitive to reduction of community area?
How is a community ecosystem formed?

plausible_answers.text: lack of property rights or lax law/regulatory enforcement

qas.question: What leads to biodiversity loss in some species?
What destroys the more diverse species?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Habitat size<b4_0/><a0_0/> and numbers of species are systematically related. <a1_0><b5_0>Physically larger species and those living at lower latitudes or in forests or oceans<b5_0/><a1_0/> are more sensitive to reduction in habitat area. <b8_0>Conversion to "trivial" standardized ecosystems<b8_0/> (e.g., <a2_0><b6_0>monoculture following deforestation<b6_0/><a2_0/>) effectively destroys habitat for the more diverse species that preceded the conversion. In some countries <a3_0><b7_0>lack of property rights or lax law/regulatory enforcement<b7_0/><a3_0/> necessarily leads to biodiversity loss (degradation costs having to be supported by the community).[citation needed]
